Title: Programming Languages
Concepts: Interpreted vs Compiled, High-level vs Low-level
Starter: Gallery Walk: Examples of code in various languages; students guess which are compiled vs interpreted
Description: Students will explore the differences between interpreted and compiled programming languages, as well as high-level versus low-level languages, through a lecture and code examples, including Processing. They will discuss real-world applications of each type. The submittable artifact is a short written reflection on one language’s use case, saved as a text file.

Title: Using an IDE
Concepts: IDE features, compile/run, debugging, syntax vs runtime vs logic errors
Starter: Quick IDE Tour: Pair-share what each button or menu in the Processing environment might do before demoing
Description: The lesson focuses on navigating the Processing environment, covering compilation, execution, and debugging. Students will practice identifying syntax, runtime, and logic errors in sample Processing code. The submittable artifact is a screenshot of a debugged .pde file with annotations explaining one error fixed.

Title: IDE Project
Starter: Mini Debugging Challenge: Find bugs in sample Processing .pde output
Description: Students will apply Processing environment skills to create a simple program, such as a basic animation or drawing, and debug it. The focus is hands-on coding and testing in Processing. The submittable artifact is the completed .pde source file.

Title: Programming Style Basics
Concepts: White space, naming conventions, constants vs variables
Starter: **Read My Code!** (5-7 mins): Show two very short Processing code snippets. One should be poorly formatted/named, the other well-formatted. Ask students which is easier to read and why.
Description: The lesson introduces programming style in Processing, emphasizing readable code through proper white space, naming conventions, and constants. Students will refactor a poorly formatted .pde file. The submittable artifact is the refactored .pde file with a brief explanation of changes made.

Title: Identifier Formats
Starter: Naming Game: Rename sloppy variables in a Processing sketch using proper conventions
Description: Students will learn about identifier formats like camelCase and snake_case, practicing their application in Processing variable naming. The focus is on writing clear, standardized code. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with renamed variables from a provided sketch.

Title: Output Formatting
Concepts: Decimal places, dollar signs, sentence formatting
Starter: **Making it Pretty** (5-7 mins): Provide students with raw data (e.g., a number like 1234.5678, a name and an age). Ask how they would display it in Processing to look professional (e.g., as text or graphics).
Description: The lesson covers formatting output in Processing for user readability, such as text or graphical displays. Students will write a Processing sketch to format sample data. The submittable artifact is a .pde file that formats numerical and string outputs.

Title: Software Development Life Cycle
Starter: Sticky Note Flowchart: Build out SDLC stages on wall posters
Description: Students will explore the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) through a group activity mapping its stages for a Processing project. They will discuss each phase’s role in programming. The submittable artifact is a flowchart of the SDLC for a hypothetical Processing app, saved as a diagram.

Title: Designing Algorithms
Starter: UML Sketch-Off: Draw a flowchart or pseudocode for a Processing-based to-do app visualization
Description: The focus is on algorithm design using UML diagrams and pseudocode for a Processing-based to-do list visualization. Students will practice top-down design principles. The submittable artifact is a UML diagram or pseudocode for the app, saved as a diagram or text file.

Title: Development Project
Concepts: Apply SDLC to a complete program
Starter: SDLC Group Sprint: Apply all stages to a Processing animation project
Description: Students will apply the SDLC to develop an animation or interactive program in Processing, from requirements to testing. The lesson emphasizes teamwork and project planning. The submittable artifact is the completed .pde file and a brief project report.

Title: Input/Output Basics
Starter: Input/Output Sorting: Categorize real-world examples of input vs output
Description: The lesson introduces input/output concepts in Processing, exploring mouse and keyboard inputs and graphical outputs. Students will analyze real-world I/O examples. The submittable artifact is a diagram categorizing five I/O examples, saved as a text or image file.

Title: Data Types Overview
Starter: **Information Sort** (5-7 mins): Provide a list of various pieces of information (e.g., "your age", "your name", "is it raining?", "your GPA"). Ask students how they would categorize each in Processing.
Description: Students will learn about basic data types (Boolean, Integer, Float, String) in Processing and their applications. They will practice declaring variables in a sketch. The submittable artifact is a .pde file demonstrating the use of all four data types.

Title: Declaring & Initializing Variables
Starter: **The Empty Box** (5-7 mins): Bring in an empty box and a toy. Explain that declaring is like labeling the box, and initializing is like putting the toy inside. Discuss why you might want to label an empty box.
Description: The focus is on variable declaration and initialization in Processing, emphasizing their differences. Students will write a sketch to declare and initialize variables. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with five properly declared and initialized variables.

Title: Arithmetic Operators
Starter: Arithmetic Showdown: Solve math with Processing code and compare to math class logic
Description: Students will explore arithmetic operators in Processing through coding exercises, using them in graphical outputs. They will write a sketch using all operators. The submittable artifact is a .pde file calculating results with each operator.

Title: Comparison & Logic Operators
Starter: Logic Card Sort: Match operators to examples and true/false results in Processing
Description: The lesson covers comparison and logic operators in Processing, focusing on their use in decision-making for animations. Students will create expressions in a sketch. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with five logical expressions and their outputs.

Title: Order of Operations
Starter: PEMMDAS Race: Students order expressions by precedence under time limit
Description: Students will learn the order of operations (PEMMDAS) in Processing, practicing with complex expressions in sketches. The focus is on correct expression evaluation. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with five evaluated expressions and comments explaining results.

Title: Expressions
Starter: Expression Match: Match valid and invalid expressions to explanations in Processing
Description: The lesson focuses on constructing syntactically correct expressions in Processing using operators and operands. Students will identify and fix invalid expressions in a sketch. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with five corrected expressions and comments.

Title: Functions & Scope
Concepts: Function use, local vs global variables
Starter: **Chef's Station** (5-7 mins): Imagine a restaurant kitchen. The 'sauce station' only knows about the ingredients for sauces (local). The 'pantry' knows about all ingredients (global). How does this help organize a Processing sketch?
Description: Students will explore functions and variable scope in Processing, writing functions for graphical tasks. The focus is on modularity in sketches. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with two functions demonstrating scope.

Title: Built-in vs User-defined Functions
Starter: **Toolbox Analogy** (5-7 mins): Show a multi-tool vs. a custom-built tool. Discuss how Processing’s built-in functions (e.g., draw()) compare to user-defined ones.
Description: The lesson compares built-in and user-defined functions in Processing, focusing on arguments and return values. Students will write a user-defined function for a sketch. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with one built-in and one user-defined function.

Title: Complex Data Types
Starter: **Organizing Your Stuff** (5-7 mins): Ask students how they organize their school supplies. Do they keep individual pencils (simple) or a whole pencil case with multiple items (complex)? Relate to Processing data storage.
Description: Students will learn about complex data types like Strings and Arrays in Processing, practicing their use in sketches. The focus is on data organization for visualizations. The submittable artifact is a .pde file using an Array and a String.

Title: Mini Project: Data & Functions
Concepts: Write program using all key concepts
Starter: Concept Map Sprint: Build a wall chart showing links between Strand 3 topics
Description: Students will create a Processing sketch combining data types, functions, and expressions, applying Strand 3 concepts. The lesson emphasizes project integration for a visual output. The submittable artifact is the .pde file and a concept map.

Title: IF Statements
Concepts: IF, ELSE IF, ELSE logic, nesting
Starter: Code Snippet Judge: Rank IF statements in Processing sketches on readability and logic
Description: The lesson introduces IF statements in Processing, including ELSE IF and ELSE, with a focus on nesting for interactive sketches. Students will write conditional logic code. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with nested IF statements.

Title: Loops: For Loops
Starter: Loop Build Challenge: Write a simple for-loop in Processing from a visual diagram
Description: Students will learn for-loop structure in Processing and practice writing loops for repetitive graphical tasks. The focus is on loop mechanics. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with a working for-loop.

Title: Loops: While Loops
Starter: While-Loop Maze: Follow a condition through a loop 'path' in a Processing sketch
Description: The lesson covers while loops in Processing, exploring their use cases for animations. Students will write a while loop program. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with a working while loop.

Title: Nested Loops & Loop Exit
Starter: Loop Ending Escape Room: Identify what ends each loop scenario in Processing
Description: Students will explore nested loops and loop exit strategies like break statements in Processing sketches. The focus is on controlling loop flow for animations. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with nested loops and a break statement.

Title: Complex Conditions
Starter: Complex Condition Mad Lib: Build silly but valid loop conditions in Processing
Description: The lesson focuses on combining relational and logical operators in loop conditions within Processing sketches. Students will write complex conditional loops. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with a loop using complex conditions.

Title: Control Structures Project
Concepts: Apply IFs and Loops in programs
Starter: IF/LOOP Bingo: Win by spotting correct use in live Processing code walkthroughs
Description: Students will create a Processing sketch combining IF statements and loops, applying Strand 4 concepts. The lesson emphasizes practical application for interactive visuals. The submittable artifact is the .pde file and a brief explanation of control structures used.

Title: Careers in Programming
Concepts: Team roles: leader, analyst, developer, SME
Starter: Career Hat Day: Match personality traits to programming job roles
Description: The lesson explores programming careers, focusing on team roles like leader and developer, with examples from Processing-based projects. Students will research one role. The submittable artifact is a one-page summary of a programming role, saved as a text file.

Title: Traits of Programmers
Starter: Team Role Drama: Perform a mini-sketch for each team role
Description: Students will discuss traits like problem-solving and collaboration essential for programmers, using Processing projects as context. They will perform a group skit. The submittable artifact is a written reflection on one programmer trait, saved as a text file.

Title: Pathways and Trends
Starter: Trend Debate: AI programming—boon or risk?
Description: The lesson covers career pathways and current trends like AI in programming, with connections to Processing’s applications. Students will debate a trend’s impact. The submittable artifact is a debate position paper on one trend, saved as a text file.

Title: Ethics in Programming
Starter: Ethics Dilemma Cards: What should a dev do in questionable scenarios?
Description: Students will explore ethical issues in programming, such as piracy and privacy, through case studies, including Processing-based software. The focus is on ethical decision-making. The submittable artifact is a written response to an ethics dilemma, saved as a text file.

Title: Impact of Software
Starter: Impact Pyramid: Stack how software affects individual → global society
Description: The lesson examines software’s impact on workplaces and society, using Processing apps as examples. Students will create an impact diagram. The submittable artifact is the diagram with annotations, saved as an image or text file.

Title: Career Exploration Project
Concepts: Present on a chosen software career
Starter: Career Pitch: 60-sec elevator pitch for a dream tech job
Description: Students will research and present on a software career, using Processing project examples to illustrate roles. The focus is on career exploration and presentation skills. The submittable artifact is a slide deck and pitch script, saved as a presentation file.

Title: Professional Skills
Starter: Skill Scenarios: Match professional traits to success stories
Description: The lesson focuses on workplace skills like communication and teamwork, with group activities contextualized by Processing projects. Students will analyze real-world scenarios. The submittable artifact is a written analysis of one scenario, saved as a text file.

Title: Vocabulary & Syntax Practice
Starter: Syntax Bee: Students fix Processing syntax on-the-fly in speed rounds
Description: Students will review key programming terms and Processing syntax through interactive exercises. The focus is on reinforcing foundational knowledge. The submittable artifact is a .pde file with corrected syntax and a completed syntax worksheet.

Title: Problem Solving Strategies
Starter: Pattern Detectives: Spot repeat logic in real-life Processing code examples
Description: The lesson covers problem-solving strategies like decomposition and pattern recognition in Processing sketches. Students will analyze code for patterns. The submittable artifact is a pattern analysis report for a Processing sketch, saved as a text file.

Title: Midterm Project
Concepts: Apply Strands 3–4 in a complete program
Starter: Midterm Launch: Gallery of Processing project prompts; students pick and plan
Description: Students will create a Processing sketch applying data types, functions, and control structures. The focus is on integrating Strands 3 and 4 for a visual output. The submittable artifact is the .pde file and a project plan.

Title: Certification Practice
Starter: Mock Cert Test: Time-based multiple choice practice
Description: The lesson prepares students for the Skill Certification Test #820 with practice questions, including Processing-related scenarios. The focus is on test-taking strategies. The submittable artifact is a completed practice test, saved as a text file.

Title: Final Project Design
Starter: Project Planner: Fill out design doc with pseudocode + diagrams for a Processing project
Description: Students will design a final Processing project, creating pseudocode and diagrams. The focus is on project planning. The submittable artifact is a design document with pseudocode and UML, saved as a text or image file.

Title: Final Project Implementation
Starter: Code Studio: Build, test, and peer review Processing projects
Description: Students will implement, test, and present their final Processing project, applying all course concepts. The focus is on execution and peer review. The submittable artifact is the final .pde file and a presentation.

Title: Reflection & Showcase
Concepts: Review progress and present learning outcomes
Starter: Reflection Wheel: Spin and speak—what did you learn, struggle with, enjoy in Processing?
Description: The lesson reflects on the course, with students presenting their learning outcomes from Processing projects. The focus is on self-assessment and celebration. The submittable artifact is a written reflection on the course experience, saved as a text file.
